ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Galaxies and their structure, kinematics, and interactions. I managed to brush up and refine my knowledge on introductory physics topics like gravity and potential, kinematics, and orbital dynamics. There was also some chemistry and fluid dynamics, but manageable after a while.
I learned more about galaxies, mergers, kinematics, etc.

Through this course, I developed a lot of knowledge about the physical processes that occur within and between galaxies and learned about numerous mathematical methods for calculating important quantities related to galaxies.
I learned a lot about galaxy structure and formation, much of which I had heard alluded to before I took this class but never learned about in detail.

This is a survey course in galaxies. Topics covered include stellar basics, chemical evolution, some spectroscopy and interpretation of spectra, galactic kinematics, spiral and elliptical structure, and active galactic nuclei.

I learned about the essential foundations of galaxies in terms of their composition and dynamics. We gained useful insights into how galaxies interact and evolve over time. We gained foundational skills in determining galactic properties such as quantifying dark matter content, determining AGN luminosities, and calculating time scales.

I learned a lot about galaxies and the reasons they evolve they way they do. I gained lots of insight about factors that influence evolution to go one way or another. Absolutely fascinating. Gained what will probably eventually feel like "common sense" about galaxies.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Prof. Kenney's lectures are jammed packed with information. It might take at least two watches to get every topic. The prerecorded lectures are extremely long on some days in addition to the live classes. The live classes can be very confusing if you didn't understand some of the topics in the prerecorded lectures, but it is mostly discussions with other students. The homework also can vary greatly in difficulty and often would require going to office hours for follow-up. However, Professor Kenney is very helpful in answering questions in email and during office hours.

The combination of 60+ minutes of recorded lecture and 75 minutes of live lecture was a bit much. This is especially because a lot of the lectures had information that was irrelevant to my performance on the problem sets or exams. That we needed a copy of the textbook to be able to do the homework was also a bit annoying. Often, there was a single student that the professor would fawn over that apparently spoke the word of God. Many of the rest of us would be told that we were incorrect in class discussion when we were actually correct or expect us to know things that he had never spoken of before or had never been covered in prior astronomy courses so that he could have his "gotcha" moment. The problem set questions were rarely worded well. One thing is that the professor seemed to actually care about the subject he was teaching, which was nice.

The course's main strength is its discussion format and engaging class periods, which helped solidify my learning. One weakness was the use of online lectures prior to the class itself, which effectively double the class time. On top of readings, this presents quite a lot of work to do to prepare for classes.

All the physics derivations in the recorded lectures were very hard to follow. Professor Kenney's logic seemed to be all over the place -- sometimes he'd be actively deriving something, sometimes he'd be stating something we'd derive later, and it was frequently impossible to tell which he was actually doing.

Professor Kenney obviously cares a lot about this course. The effort that he puts in benefits students greatly. The format of this class is the best that I have experienced in the pandemic era. I quite enjoyed the results from research that he would show to motivate material from class. However, oftentimes, Professor Kenney's questions would be confusingly worded and he would allot far more or less time to discussion than we needed. It was also a bit frustrating, sometimes, to be placed in groups with certain other students.
Well taught course. Live zoom classes were fun and well planned out, made us think and interact.
1 and a half hour recorded lecture on top of virtual lecture is too much

The strength was that this course was incredibly interactiveI found that working through live-session problems in small groups was a great way to talk through some of the material and get comfortable with participating. The weakness was definitely the time commitment; we had both asynchronous lectures and synchronous meetings totaling way over the allotted class time, on top of weekly psets.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The online discussions were done really well, and the use of Zoom polls and breakout rooms was quite effective in strengthening my learning.
The discussions we had during the zoom meetings were often fun and engaging.

This has been the class best organized for the pandemic era. The engagement that this class required ensured that students would learn instead of dozing off, and it broke up the monotony of pandemic lockdown Yale-won't-let-us-do-anything humdrum.

Live zoom sessions were useful to get to know other astro classmates and interact with people whereas many of us would have had little human interaction. Recorded lectures in nicely cut segments were useful for learning and reviewing.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, but be ready for a fire hose of information to the face. I recommend you remind yourself of basic physics beforehand (Newton's Laws of Gravity and Orbital Dynamics).
It's required for the astro major so do you have a choice?
Probably not. The lessons were often poorly explained, and the class required a lot of work (two ~1-1.5 hour recorded lectures a week in addition to two live classes).

I would, as the discussions are quite engaging and make the learning interesting; come exam time, I felt it easier to recall much of the info. That being said, I would caution against the volume of work due to the pre-lecture materials, although this may not be a part of the class in normal times.
If you have any interest in astronomy and know what the HR diagram is, this course is for you! This is a very well-taught survey of many topics important in astrophysics.
Yes, fantastic course for astro or interested physics students! You'll so much about star processes and factors of galaxy evolution that it will feel like common sense at the end of the course.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: prerecorded lecture and live virtual lectures
recorded lecture
It was a flipped class so we had recorded lectures and live lectures.
Recorded lecture + twice weekly virtual lectures and discussion
There are also asynchronous lectures to watch before the class itself.
We had recorded lectures before each Zoom meeting, and then we had seminar-style Zoom discussions during class time.
To great effect, this class combined recorded lectures with discussions during the scheduled class time.
recorded lecture
Recorded lectures to watch before class, then in class lecture and discussions
Recorded lecture
virtual seminar (live sessions accompanying each lecture)
